newsitem.title: UK: Legal & General up after Lehman comment.
newsitem.headline: Legal & General up after Lehman comment.

text.p: Shares in Legal & General Plc rose to a record high in a strong insurance sector on Monday as analysts at Lehman Brothers repeated an "outperform" rating on the stock and set a 12-month price target of 400p.
The stock was up 8p at 354 by 1214 GMT, after earlier touching 347p, beating the previous high of 347p set Friday.

Others in the sector, which benefits from strong financial markets and low interest rates, also rose with Prudential Corp Plc up 8-1/2p at 477, Commercial Union Plc up 11p at 655-1/2 and General Accident Plc up 6-1/2p at 730-1/2.
Analyst Rob Proctor at Lehman said he raised his estimates for Legal & General's pre-tax profit in 1996 and 1997 by about eight percent to 311 million stg and 352 million respectively.
He raised his dividend expectations for to 11.25p in 1996 and to 13.00p for the year after.
Proctor said Legal & General had managed to positively surprise the markets for the past two-to-three years and there was scope for more to come.
He pointed to strong new business figures from the company, and said it was winning new business at a rate which was about three times the industry average.

The Lehman analyst said there was scope for L&G to be the target of a takeover bid as the industry consolidates, but it was the solid operating performance which mainly underpinned his positive opinion of the stock.
